    −
Believing that one is doing good for another because they are acting how they would like to be treated. This ignores the fact that personal likes/dislikes imposed on others is not a good deed if they are unwelcome. By not doing bad unto others, one decreases the possibility of undesirable consequences returned on them, retaliation, revenge, social ostracism. "Do unto others as you would have them do to you" when stated conversely as a negative rule, the message is "Don't do bad unto others in order to avoid retaliation." This is not a moral code. However, "love your neighbor as yourself" could be considered a moral guideline, but no more profound than "be kind."
